It was good, and my only complaint is they didn't heat the meat long enough.  Anyway stop in and trust me, or Yelp, or, the precious bartender that understands the need to recharge your device.

If you are looking to take that special guy friend on a man date, this is the place! Solid taps and specials? Check. Variety of gourmet sandwiches? Check. Intimate but not romantic atmosphere? Check. Rhetorical questions? Check.   Are you are looking for a new restaurant on state to explore? Try Roast and let your bromance flourish.

"Coopers meets Frat House".   The food was good, but service was lacking.  Not really clear whether there's wait service or whether you're supposed to go to the counter and just pay there. It would be nice if someone came to greet you as you arrived. I didn't get the feeling that any of the staff had worked in the service industry before- they all looked like 'someone's girlfriend' filling a shift.  One side of the pub looks like a cosy, sophisticated brick house brasserie, the other side looks like a student's bedroom wall- goodness knows what goes on in the basement where the ping pong table is...  While the food was tasty, the young staff should work on their interactions with the customers, engaging with them more to make us feel more welcome.  That being said, I'd come back for another sandwich if walking along state st.
The food is great here. Ownership clearly has decided to ignore customer and employee satisfaction by not staffing adequately. You have a great restaurant, treat it that way.

The food was underwhelming compared to the decor and aesthetics of the restaurant. The food is served on plastic plates suitable for a play set.   We ordered appetizers including wings, curds and nachos. All were mediocre. My sandwich was served on a burnt piece of bread accompanied by cold fries.   I would come here for a drink at the bar but don't expect much from the food.

SO MUCH LOVE HERE. I love this place to death. The cheese curds are INSANE and there are so many different sandwiches and I always get something different. I'm going to miss this place a lot when I leave Madison!

Went in for brunch at noon. Party of...3 on a weekend day. Not that busy.  Right now this is some of the worst service and food on state steet.  All of my party is out First time here, not like anybody would ask us.   Seated and greeted. Ordered some drinks, soda, coffee, cocktail. The coffee was awful, it was sitting for a few hours and kinda cold. The second cup, which I had to request since nobody was going to ask for refills on their own accord apparently...(wait..is this brunch?) Was *hotter* but still bad and tasteless. Seems like they use real cheap stuff. I had to get a real cup of coffee after we left.  One person in my party thought they cocktail tasted like "cheap rail" and was done really poorly. That person didn't order a second drink. Not worth the 10-13$ that i'm sure it as.  Food took over thirty mins to come to the table. Bacon was chewy and in my opinion, simply gross. Eggs were bland, the toast wasn't even toasted, and the potatoes were just okay. The other people in my party did not enjoy their meals and I'm not even sure if we were asked how it was overall.  Definitely will not be back or recommend. Maybe they should focus on operating only in the evening and using higher quality products.

In a word, delicious.  With a changing and diverse tap list, a rustic yet eclectic look, and some seriously flavorful sandwiches, I keep going back. The bartenders are attentive and knowledgable, it's clean and well-maintained, and the food is fresh, offering up great options for every taste.  The only downfall is the usual wait time of 30-45 minutes for a table. But if you don't mind eating at the bar, it's usually just a few minutes to find a couple of empty stools. Totally fine by me.  I have to recommend the Grateful Red buffalo chicken sandwich, too. And the house chips. Fabulous.
Obviously I love this place; great quality food and an absolutely incredible tap list... what's not to love?

I want to preface this with the "I've only been there once" statement.   Unfortunately, it didn't live up to what I had hoped and dreamed it would be. After a month long strict paleo diet, I dove into the grilled cheese with bacon & tomato. It was simple. Not inedible but nothing to rave about. (I heart raving about food.)   My co-workers were equally "ok'd". I'll give it another try but I won't go out of my way.   (As a note, I had a side salad for my side and it too, was nothing spectacular.) I think I just expect too much in Madison.

We can start by saying that we have been here five times and are always incredibly disappointed with roast.  The food is good, I'll give them that. The sweet potato fries are great and I do really like their burger specials.  That being said, no matter how busy or empty it is, we have never ever gotten good service. Just today we waited in line for ten minutes behind three people with open tables everywhere. Apparently it takes them ten minutes to process a to go order and they make everyone else wait.  Don't expect to get your water refilled, don't expect to get visited by wait staff during the meal. Don't expect to get visited when you're ready to pay. Get used to walking up and asking for everything.  Decor is cool and the food is great but bad service is inexcusable and continually prevents us from eating here.  Edit: have eaten here recently and gotten much better service.

I've visited Roast Public House twice in the past couple of months and have had mixed results.  While my Restaurant Week visit came close to attaining rarified 5 star territory, a subsequent lunch time visit fell lamentably flat.   Since I do enjoy the welcoming setting and the friendly service, I'm willing to return with hopes that the quality of the food becomes more consistent.  While the decidedly mixed Yelp reviews initially gave me pause when considering Roast as a lunch option, their enticing Restaurant Week lunch menu was too tempting to keep me away. The appetizer course, Braised Pork Belly (roasted heirloom carrots, blood orange vinaigrette, toasted cumin crme fraiche, warm baguette) got things off to a rousing start.  I could detect the unctuous pork aroma as my server approached my table with the dish. The meat had a gorgeous sear, which boosted the already luxuriant flavor of the dish and paired wonderfully with the roasted carrots. Unfortunately, the baguette was no longer warm when it arrived at my table and would have benefited from more toasting and a more generous application of the crme fraiche. Wonderfully composed and expertly executed and plated, this dish showcased of the talent of the Roast kitchen staff.   The same platitudes apply to the main course, the Roasted Pork sandwich (whiskey lime pork BBQ, maple glazed onions, ancho chili slaw on a toasted ciabatta roll). Roast did a fantastic job of optimizing the flavors from each of the sandwiches components.  The addition of the maple glazed onions were a brilliant move - creating an intoxicating interplay between the richness of the pulled pork,  the subtle sweetness of the onions and the tanginess of the slightly spicy slaw. While the generous portion of the pork was a wee bit dry, that problem was solved by the lightly dressed slaw. The satisfying ciabatta roll was the perfect foil for the rest of the sandwich, providing appreciated flavor and texture.    The homemade potato chips that came as a side deserve a separate paragraph.  Perfectly browned and seasoned, they make me want to swear off grocery store chips for life.  It takes extra effort for a restaurant to make their own chips but the results for the dining experience made it oh so worth it.   Unfortunately, Roast kind of crapped the bed with the dessert course (a blueberry rhubarb crumb bar with vanilla ice cream). It was like 50 shades of bland, under baked and lacking any crunch. They went overboard with the citrus component, but even that could not overcome the blandness of the cream cheese and flavorless vanilla ice cream.  Come on Roast, go big or go home. You offered big, bold flavors for the first two courses, why did you wimp out with a weak-ass dessert?  Weak execution also plagued my subsequent visit to Roast, as my chicken tacos (a lunch time special for $2) suffered from dry, under-seasoned meat and a bland corn tortilla that fell apart when I attempted to pick it up.  It appeared very little thought went into the composition of the dish, no attempt was made to dress up the chicken with any technique or seasoning.  The potato skins we ordered as an appetizer were under-salted and not all that memorable.   My dining companion did enjoy her Bacon Swiss burger though.   I know some of my fellow Yelpers have had less than kind words for the service they received at Roast, but I've experienced friendly, attentive service during both of my visits.  This was especially true during my Restaurant Week visit where my server checked in after each course.  I'm also a fan of Roast's rustic chic interior, with the exposed cream-colored white brick and natural wood highlights.  The use of brown as the main color theme was apropos, as it reminded me of the color of roasted meat.  While the back of the restaurant is dark, the front benefits from the natural light from the front windows facing State Street.  Overall, it is a comfortable setting for a meal or a couple of beers with friends at the bar.  While the food can vary in quality, the potential of the kitchen for inspired cuisine will draw me back from time to time.

I love the atmosphere. If they had free wifi, I could totally see myself camping out in a corner of the dining area for an afternoon.  As a first-timer to RPH, I ordered the giambotta but chose not to switch out the side of chips. The meat was well-cooked, but it definitely did not constitute what I'd typically consider pulled pork...this was the first disappointment. Second, it was WAY, WAY too salty for my taste, and I'm not usually very sensitive to sodium. Blech. I had half my sandwich and I couldn't have anymore (it wasn't because I was full, it was because I could feel my taste buds shriveling..). Thus, RPH lands a mere three stars in my book.   I'm not willing to discount it just yet because of all the other rave reviews..but I'm sorry to say that RPH did not live up to the hype! I think I'll give RPH another go at a later date. I'm really hoping that another sandwich (or the sweet potato fries?!?!) will redeem the giambotta. Crossing my fingers!

When we got to the restaurant, we were immediately sat at a table and then no one greeted us for 10 minutes. No water. No "Hey guys, thanks for waiting. We're super swamped and it will be just a minute." Nothing. They were decently busy, but like I said - there was no wait and a handful of empty tables when we walked in.  The menu looked enticing and we knew what we wanted to eat and drink by the time someone greeted us. I ordered a chicken bruschetta sandwich with sweet potato fries and a side of lime aioli sauce.   Our food and beer came out very quickly once our order was placed, which was nice. The sandwich was average at best, and about halfway through the sandwich, I realized the chicken breast was probably 50% cooked. What the heck ....  I stopped eating it and had the rest tossed, but was very underwhelmed. Additionally, my fries were served with a chipotle ranch sauce, which was tasty, but not what I ordered.  Meh, I'll try something else on State St. next time.

Take note that I never actually ate AT the restaurant, only ordered my food to go, so my rating is for the quality/price/flavor of the food. When I lived in Madison, this place was on the regular rotation for lunch, about once every month. It never disappointed.

I have been to this restaurant a handful of times, and I've always been pleased with the food and the service. However, my experience at brunch this morning was not so enjoyable. The food was excellent as per usual; I would highly recommend the "sassy sconnie" as it was packed with flavor. Our waitress on the other hand was complacent. When she placed things onto our table she did so aggressively and seemed hostile. She did not ask how we were doing after serving our meals, and took forever to refill my sisters bottomless mimosa. When I paid in cash and asked for my change she didn't return the correct amount to me, and in fact short-changed me. I would totally recommend giving this place a visit, but just request to have any server other than Silvia.

I have to confess something...  I hate eating on State St. There.  I said it.  I feel better.  I don't know what it is, I really don't. Maybe it's because when I moved here so many people warned me that it's a bit of a dump, overloaded with college chains and suggested I avoid it? Whatever the case may be it's really hard to get me excited about anything over there... except Roast. It's a little weird that you have to walk to the end of the restaurant to order, but if you can get over some of the structural things (and get over them, they just won't change) it's  amazingly good. I've worked my way through the menu and can safely say everything I've eaten has rocked... the crispy buffalo chicken wrap topping the list. Whatever you decide to get, add the sweet potato fries - they're some of the best I've eaten in Madison; hot, crispy, and deliciously fluffy on the inside. And the bbq sauce they're served with?! Don't even get me started, I would drink it if I thought nobody would look at me and judge.  Only flaw? What's with the lack of locals on tap dudes? There are some solid Midwestern beers but when it comes to the Madison specific options, there aren't many. Wah, wah.

Fried chees curds were decent but really greasy and I found it hard to eat very many. Kale ceaser was okay but bland. The portobello sandwich was a disaster and I sent it back. Couldn't bite or cut thru the thick sourdough crust without the contents bursting out all over the place. Was very sloppy. Whole roasted red peppers on top of portobello mushrooms made it very slippery. I get that this isn't there specialty, but take it off the menu if you can't execute it correctly. Good beer selection. Really unenthusiastic wait staff on my visit that seemed like they were awaiting execution. I could see it being a great place if they worked on a few areas. For what it's worth They did take the sandwich off my bill without me even asking that's not always the case with some places.

Roast is a great addition to Madison's ever growing food scene.  Good sandwiches are sort of lacking in the city, so Roast helps fill some of that void.     First off, it was a difficult decision on what to order!  Roast offers probably over 15 different sandwiches, all of which looked delicious on paper.  I finally opted for the white cap roast beef - a roast beef sandwich served on a quality baguette and topped with caramelized onions and mozzarella cheese.  The beef is also drenched in its own drippings.  Overall, I was a pleased customer, as the combo of the items complimented each other well.  The meat was, however, slightly overcooked.  All sandwiches include chips, but I paid an extra $1 for a huge serving of their hand cut fries.  The fries were super good, hot (which means fresh), and included a side of a Siracha lime aioli.  Generally, sandwiches run from $8-10.  Didn't get to slam a beer down since I had a lot of obligations.  Showing up to a meeting with my faculty from my department with the Asian flush would given them cause to revoke my diploma.  However, they do seem to have a large selection of beers.  I'll have to return at a later time!

Good atmosphere. Staff is friendly. Food is good but the menu is limited. Sandwiches are much better than the salads. When they first opened they had a ping pong table downstairs but it has sadly disappeared.

I have to agree with just about all the other reviews here - great food, great beer list, but not 5 stars as a little help with how the whole place works would be nice.  Better signage maybe?  Anyway, we had a turkey sandwich with brie and a cranberry relish (I think), fries, and a salad.  It was all excellent, including the fries, and the salad had a nice variety of fresh greens with dressing on the side as requested.  Overall I'll go back, although it'd be nice to have one tab - food and beer all together - instead of ordering food and then turning around to the bar and ordering beer.

Oooh, I love Roast Public House! A sweet spot, a little hard to find in the middle of State Street, but maybe that's why it's so cool...most tables were full but not packed and it wasn't loud at all. I liked the vibe...not commercial at all and a little bit of a cozy feel, but spacious.  My friend and I sat at the bar. The bartenders were awesome, super nice, and attentive. They even gave us Hershey kisses after our meal!   My Roasted Eggplant Napoleon sandwich was delish! My friend had the daily special sandwich which included pulled pork with some sort of bruschetta topping. She loved it! Prices are reasonable, sandwiches are big and filling, and they have daily drink specials. We got a pitcher of New Belgium seasonal beer for $9!!!  Roast has a downstairs area with ping pong, darts, and a large TV. Plenty of TVs upstairs for game watching as well. I can't wait to go back!

Really good food, atmosphere, but terrible service. We did not really have a consistent waiter the entire time, and we ordered 3 soups, yet none of them ever came. However, the food is very good and their house chips are amazing!
They charged 21 dollars for a pitcher of flat Guinness. The food is not bad but I will not be coming back.
Over priced; soggy sweet potatoes fries, half the pulled pork was straight fat, and the "apple" slaw tasted nothing of apples. There are a lot better options to eat at in this area.

Nice looking place with outdoor sidewalk seating. Menu was small but did offer some healthy choices all around $10. They had a very big alcohol selection to offer with the menu. Overall would say the food was average.

Grilled cheese with avocado. Awesome. Service was fine. My glass was always full. Only complaint would be I sat at the bar and wouldn't have minded chatting a little but the server didn't seem to feel the same way. Otherwise friendly environment.

Fantastic sandwiches and cocktails. Clearly they put a ton of thought into their menu and execute everything quite well. Sometimes the difference between a good sandwich and a great one is just the bread, that's what puts them over the top. One of the better Cuban sandwiches I've had in a while. Solid service as well.

This has always been a go to place for me. The place has all of the beer and food you could ever ask for. The menus get a 5 star the service is pulling it down though. They are nice servers but they are slow and not the brightest.   It's a couple of young guys owning it and it seems like they are hiring based on friendships not competency. But even lack of service can't put a negative spin on this place. I am obsessed with their beef brisket. And don't forget the sweet potato fries. I'm salivating just thinking about it.

ARE YOU OUT OF CHEESE?!?  THIS IS WISCONSIN!!!    Ordered the chicken nachos thinking they sounded delicious...I was wrong. I ordered them without lettuce and olives (my girlfriend is allergic to olives) and went to pick them up ten minutes later. Got home, opened the box, and BOOM olives. No big deal these things happen, but after looking closer there was two chunks of tiny chicken, barely any cheese, and cold. I called the guy at the checkout (Adam was his name) and explained to him what was going on(he was kind and took the ticket correct) he handed the phone over to his manager Spencer who seemed very short and not to happy to talk to me. (Mute the phone when handing it over cause we can here ya, brah)       Yada yada ya they replaced the nachos. I Pick them up, get home, open box and the nachos still suck. No cheese, bland dry chicken, cold, and one big piece of lettuce mixed in I feel just to spite my complaint.        I was super excited to finally try out roast and was severely let done...twice.  This is clearly "nacho" thang. I'll be going to brick house bbq for my nachos from here on out.

We are visiting Madison and were excited to try this very crowded and popular place. We waited about 30 minutes, no problem. Staff is friendly and the cheese curds were delicious. The burgers were unfortunately terrible. We ordered 2 medium rare and you could tell that the patties were probably cooked in the morning and were extremely over cooked and barely edible. Disappointed...

Food is great, service is lacking. I've been going to Roast every now and then over the past few years, and I've come to terms with the fact that their service is very hit or miss.   I was super bummed on my last visit - a friend and I were there for brunch, and the only people in the restaurant. Our waiter was friendly, but didn't write down either of our food orders. Usually I don't mind this, but once he got to entering them in a few minutes later, he had to call over and ask my friend which of the scrambles she ordered. And when our food was brought out, I noticed immediately that I did not get what I ordered. I felt bad saying anything because I didn't want to make them rush to remake something, and I didn't want to make my friend wait to eat, so I just ate what he brought. But that was really disappointing. At least my friend got the right scramble!  If their service was just a little better I think I would definitely visit Roast more often, because I really do like their food! They seem to have changed up their menu quite a bit over the past year or so -- they used to have mainly sandwiches where they were split up on the menu by the type of meat they were made with -- beef, pork, and poultry. Now they've moved to less sandwich options but other options, like bowls and salads. Thankfully they kept those Sweet Potato Fries on there -- because wow those are up there among my favorite sweet potato fries ever (DLUX has good ones as well)!! They're more shaped like traditional chips, flatter and just a bit wider, and when you get the chipotle ranch on the side... oh man they are SO GOOD!   I like how at Roast you can switch up your order and turn a sandwich into a wrap or vice versa! I really liked doing that with items on their old menu, but a lot of those items are sadly gone. However I'm eager to try some of the new menu items, like the Pigs Fly and Supper Club bowls and the Guacamelt.   I know I'll be returning to Roast (and ordering sweet potato fries, obviously), but with a little more hesitance now due to their unreliable/inconsistent service.

This place was great, definitely worth checking out on a game day or hitting up if one of the nicer places downtown has a long wait.  I went for brunch with a friend on a Sunday to catch the beginning of some NFL games. The space is bright and open, but lacking in some areas that could easily be improved. The bar: impeccable. The awkward space between the bar and dining room that has random wires/storage sticking out: not so much.  As far as drinks/brews go, they had a pretty nice selection and I enjoyed the Oberon I got. My friend got a Bloody Mary, which he said was also pretty good.  The selection of breakfast items was a bit weak, as it seemed most of them were just different combinations of the same 5 items, but my egg sandwich with avocado was really good when it came out. I was impressed that they had the veggie options they did with a name like "Roast."  I would definitely go back but wouldn't put it high on the list. Fun for a quick lunch or dinner before hitting the town.

The Roast is a nice place in State Street to get a better meal than your average sandwich.  They have a good variety of food, but the wait can sometimes be long.  The food itself is pretty good, but I have had better in Madison.

Roast has a great variety of delicious sandwiches and wraps.   Every sandwich I've tried has been very good.  The sauces are also very good...zesty lime aioli, imperial stout BBQ...YUM.    The sweet potato fries are awesome.  They are a thicker cut fry with a crispy outside and a soft inside. I would definitely recommend.  The service is OK, but not great.  I've had better luck with service when I sit at the bar, so I tend to grab a seat at the bar.

We stopped in this place on a Saturday and saw that you order at the counter, so we grabbed a couple of menus and started deciding on what we wanted.  While we were looking, an employee stopped by to ask if we had been there before and if we knew how it worked.  Appreciated that he made sure we knew what we were doing, instead of letting us fumble blindly through the experience.  I ordered the Jersey Joe - turkey, roast beef, Swiss and coleslaw on a marble rye with a Russian dressing/sauce on the side.  My partner got the Cuban.  Sandwiches come with chips and we ordered a side of fries to share.  The sandwiches were HUGE and great!  They were both piled high with meat, and the meat was tender and delicious!  The fries were not for me, they were the hand cut type, but I am more a fan of the McDonald's french fry...crisp and golden.  Just personal preference, and I always try to sample the fries where we eat.  They have a huge beer selection, and surprisingly, some of the best iced tea I have had in a long time!  We will definitely go back and try another sandwich, since there are many to choose from.  There are also salads and some appetizers.  The staff were all friendly and efficient, no complaints there.  Great place to grab lunch if you are on State St.

Having gotten food-poisoning from Jimmy John's on State St. and undercooked chicken from the Chipotle, I am very careful about where I'll eat near campus; I never worry about Roast!  Their beer-list and menu are thoughtfully crafted and their atmosphere is warm and inviting with a touch of shabby-chic.  They generally offer pub fare with an innovative twist that rarely disappoints.  The disadvantages, however, are that around 10:00 on Thursday (perhaps Friday as well?) they try to turn themselves into a dance club, rendering all conversation impossible.  Furthermore, they are a little pricey for the amount of food you get, thoughtfully prepared though it may be...

I have been here a few times now, mainly for brunch, but also dinner.   Brunch is amazing. Every time I have been in for brunch I have been able to get a seat right away. Service has been great. And the food, SO GOOD. I am a huge mimosa fan, so the bottomless mimosa is pretty great. $15 is a little steep, though, I must say.   Dinner was great, too! They have a "breakfast all day" sandwich (can you sense a theme here? I am a breakfast food kinda girl). I have had this twice now. I really, really enjoy it. They allow you to sub for avocado if you prefer at no extra charge which is nice.   I am docking one star just because on one occasion that I was there, a friend who I was dining with had to send their meal back as it came out cold. They fixed the mistake, but by the time the hot food came back, everyone else was nearly finished. I'm sure it was just a fluke. I will still continue to eat here for sure.
